author: potuz
content:
<@425274498732916736> re https://twitter.com/chfast/status/1687723174404743168?t=YhosOBCD5OZ9WKR59OhHNQ&s=19
Definitely, I only added uint256 support because we need an opaque type for Bellatrix beacon blocks (honestly never understood why we don't pass those as bytes instead of changing the consensus layer to support a new type). But if we move to ssz on transactions then we will need large uints in different places. I'm open to using whatever library is used in the Ethereum ecosystem for large uints. The only thing that I'd like is that at least on little endian systems the memory representation of these types is exactly their serialization. I think ssz+ is probably broken anyway for uint256 on big endian systems (don't have a machine to test)

author: chfast
content:
It wasn't super serious, but I can see some benefits of intx over what you used (can be inline, have some serialization/deseralization helpers). But I'm not sure where are you going to use it. I expect for sole ssz impl any 32-byte container type should work.

Anyway, ping me if you need contributions in this area.

author: potuz
content: Thanks! So at this stage is empty if no one uses it (ssz++). If there's anyone that is willing to use ssz++ and has intx as big int then it's a no brainer to switch. A cursory look and it seems that all your ints are stored as contiguous arrays of 64 uints so that would work for sure on little endian systems for me and most probably would work on 64 bit big endian as well
